greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows, T(n,k) = 1 if k is prime, 0 otherwise; 1 <= k <= n.
comment: Row sums = A000720, PrimePi(n), the number of primes through n: (0, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 4, 4, ...).
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for the first 100 rows, flattened
formula: Triangle read by rows, T(n,k) = 1 if k is prime, 0 otherwise; 1 <= k <= n. A000012 * (A010051 * 0^(n-k)). A010051 * 0^(n-k) = an infinite lower triangular matrix with A010051 (the characteristic function of the primes) as the main diagonal and the rest zeros. The multiplier A000012 takes partial sums of column terms.
example: First few rows of the triangle =
mathematica: Table[If[PrimeQ[k], 1, 0], {n, 1, 20}, {k, 1, n}] // Flatten (* _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 17 2017 *)
program: (PARI) for(n=1,10, for(k=1,n, print1(if(isprime(k),1,0), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 17 2017
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 23 2008
